channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-6136] got "java.net.SocketException: Invalid argument" exception
item.description:
The route can be runned on RHEL7.2, but on RHEL6.8. got the exception :

14:08:25,538 | WARN  | 9 - Test Threads | PhaseInterceptorChain            | 74 - org.apache.cxf.cxf-core - 3.0.4.redhat-621159 | Interceptor for {http://camel.apache.org/cxf/jaxws/dispatch}DefaultSEIService#{http://camel.apache.org/cxf/jaxws/dispatch}Invoke has thrown exception, unwinding now
 
org.apache.cxf.interceptor.Fault: Could not send Message.
 
	at org.apache.cxf.interceptor.MessageSenderInterceptor$MessageSenderEndingInterceptor.handleMessage(MessageSenderInterceptor.java:64)[74:org.apache.cxf.cxf-core:3.0.4.redhat-621159]

	at org.apache.camel.processor.Pipeline.process(Pipeline.java:121)[205:org.apache.camel.camel-core:2.15.1.redhat-621159]

Caused by: java.net.ConnectException: ConnectException invoking http://0.0.0.1/test/type/1234567: Invalid argument

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Xiaohui Wu Considering it's working on RHEL 7.2 I suspect it's a network configuration issue for RHEL 6.8 and not for JBoss Fuse. Are you sure the network configuration is really identical between your RHEL 7.2 and 6.8? There must be something wrong with the local network binding configuration. What happens if you change the address from 0.0.0.1 to some real external address?

If I change 0.0.0.1 to some real external address like 127.0.0.1 or real external IP like 10.66.218.175, got

Caused by: java.net.ConnectException: Connection refused
 
	at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.socketConnect(Native Method)[:1.8.0_102]
 
	at java.net.AbstractPlainSocketImpl.doConnect(AbstractPlainSocketImpl.java:350)[:1.8.0_102]

	at sun.net.www.protocol.http.HttpURLConnection.plainConnect(HttpURLConnection.java:999)[:1.8.0_102]
 
	at sun.net.www.protocol.http.HttpURLConnection.connect(HttpURLConnection.java:933)[:1.8.0_102]
 
	at sun.net.www.protocol.http.HttpURLConnection.getOutputStream0(HttpURLConnection.java:1283)[:1.8.0_102]
 
	at sun.net.www.protocol.http.HttpURLConnection.getOutputStream(HttpURLConnection.java:1258)[:1.8.0_102]
 
	at org.apache.cxf.transport.http.URLConnectionHTTPConduit$URLConnectionWrappedOutputStream.setupWrappedStream(URLConnectionHTTPConduit.java:183)[96:org.apache.cxf.cxf-rt-transports-http:3.0.4.redhat-621159]
 
	at org.apache.cxf.transport.http.HTTPConduit$WrappedOutputStream.handleHeadersTrustCaching(HTTPConduit.java:1307)[96:org.apache.cxf.cxf-rt-transports-http:3.0.4.redhat-621159]
 
	at org.apache.cxf.transport.http.HTTPConduit$WrappedOutputStream.onFirstWrite(HTTPConduit.java:1267)[96:org.apache.cxf.cxf-rt-transports-http:3.0.4.redhat-621159]

	at org.apache.cxf.io.AbstractWrappedOutputStream.write(AbstractWrappedOutputStream.java:47)[74:org.apache.cxf.cxf-core:3.0.4.redhat-621159]

	... 26 more

In my RHEL 7.2 env I got the same java.net.ConnectException: Invalid argument error, too:

Caused by: java.net.ConnectException: Invalid argument
 
	at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.socketConnect(Native Method)[:1.8.0_101]
 
	at java.net.AbstractPlainSocketImpl.doConnect(AbstractPlainSocketImpl.java:350)[:1.8.0_101]
 
	at java.net.AbstractPlainSocketImpl.connectToAddress(AbstractPlainSocketImpl.java:206)[:1.8.0_101]
 
	at java.net.AbstractPlainSocketImpl.connect(AbstractPlainSocketImpl.java:188)[:1.8.0_101]

	at org.apache.cxf.transport.http.URLConnectionHTTPConduit$URLConnectionWrappedOutputStream.setupWrappedStream(URLConnectionHTTPConduit.java:236)[118:org.apache.cxf.cxf-rt-transports-http:3.1.5.redhat-630187]

	at org.apache.cxf.transport.http.URLConnectionHTTPConduit$URLConnectionWrappedOutputStream.onFirstWrite(URLConnectionHTTPConduit.java:267)[118:org.apache.cxf.cxf-rt-transports-http:3.1.5.redhat-630187]
 
	at org.apache.cxf.io.AbstractWrappedOutputStream.write(AbstractWrappedOutputStream.java:47)[74:org.apache.cxf.cxf-core:3.1.5.redhat-630187]
 
	at org.apache.cxf.io.AbstractThresholdOutputStream.write(AbstractThresholdOutputStream.java:69)[74:org.apache.cxf.cxf-core:3.1.5.redhat-630187]
 
	at org.apache.cxf.transport.http.HTTPConduit$WrappedOutputStream.close(HTTPConduit.java:1333)[118:org.apache.cxf.cxf-rt-transports-http:3.1.5.redhat-630187]

Xiaohui Wu So now I strongly suspect it's a problem specific to the routing table config in your RHEL 7.2 installation. After confirmation, we should close this ticket.
Duplicate of ENTESB-6137. We'll focus on ENTESB-6137 to resolve the original issue.

The issue appears to be two-fold:

  1. Mysteriously, the route throws this warning only on RHEL 6.8 (I even tested it on CentOS 6.8 but not reproducible there): 

    14:08:25,538 | WARN  | 9 - Test Threads | PhaseInterceptorChain            | 74 - org.apache.cxf.cxf-core - 3.0.4.redhat-621159 | Interceptor for {http://camel.apache.org/cxf/jaxws/dispatch}DefaultSEIService#{http://camel.apache.org/cxf/jaxws/dispatch}Invoke has thrown exception, unwinding now

  2. When the above exception is thrown internally, the route seems to discontinue even if it's protected by Try/Catch DSL.

While solving #1 should resolve ENTESB-6136, currently I speculate that solving #2 may possibly resolve ENTESB-6137.

A simplified reproducer (camel-cxf-http-async.zip) attached. Run:

$ mvn clean test

inside the project to reproduce the issue. The test fails only when it's run on RHEL 6.8, otherwise (including CentOS 6.8) it passes green. Changing JDK vendors and versions have no effect, so it shouldn't be an issue with any JDK impl.

Freeman(Yue) Fang Thanks for the info, Freeman!

However, adding -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true doesn't have effects for my test case on RHEL 6.8. Previously I suspected that it's solely a network configuration issue for a specific machine, but now I'm thinking a bit differently and there are two potential problems with this issue. Please note that in my test case not 0.0.0.1 but localhost:12345 is used so the routing table shouldn't be an issue.

The first problem is in CXF: Somehow camel-cxf and cxf-rt-transports-http-hc throw a different exception only on RHEL 6.8. I've digged into it and so far found that in my test case SharedOutputBuffer is shut down earlier [1] than HTTPConduit tries to close the output stream [2].
[1] https://github.com/apache/cxf/blob/cxf-3.1.8/rt/transports/http-hc/src/main/java/org/apache/cxf/transport/http/asyncclient/SharedOutputBuffer.java#L231
[2] https://github.com/apache/cxf/blob/cxf-3.1.8/rt/transports/http/src/main/java/org/apache/cxf/transport/http/HTTPConduit.java#L1333
We need to investigate why SharedOutputBuffer is closed earlier or who closes it only on RHEL 6.8. Do you have any ideas why/how it happens?

The second problem is in Camel: When the Camel Try/Catch DSL is used with an asynchronous endpoint like to("cxf://http://..."), the Catch part and subsequent steps in the entire route are executed in a different (callback) thread. That itself is ok, but when some unexpected exception occurs like the above first problem, then the subsequent Camel exchange somehow remains holding the exception which should have been handled in the Catch clause, thus terminates the remaining steps in the entire route. (I haven't yet unraveled the precise mechanism of how it happens, though.)

This is what I've investigated so far. I'll continue investigating it.

I identified the root cause. This is yet another instance of familiar client-callback-invoked-twice issues: CAMEL-2994, CXF-5629.

The first CXF issue happens when the callback for Apache HC HttpAsyncClient [1] is invoked and thus shuts down SharedOutputBuffer earlier than HTTPConduit tries to write it before closing itself [2].
[1] https://github.com/apache/cxf/blob/cxf-3.1.8/rt/transports/http-hc/src/main/java/org/apache/cxf/transport/http/asyncclient/AsyncHTTPConduit.java#L464
[2] https://github.com/apache/cxf/blob/cxf-3.1.8/rt/transports/http-hc/src/main/java/org/apache/cxf/transport/http/asyncclient/SharedOutputBuffer.java#L231
Why it happens so reliably only on RHEL 6.8 is still unclear (probably due to some thread scheduling logic specific to the kernel for RHEL 6.8), but since it's essentially an ordering issue for two distinct threads in theory it can happen on any platforms. At this moment I don't know if we need to do anything with this issue per se, as using CXF client callback in combination with Apache HC HttpAsyncClient is a highly multithreaded setting so users probably should expect such an threading issue to occur.

The second Camel issue is the real problem here. When the above issue happens, the interceptor chain's fault observer is invoked twice, once from the response workqueue thread [3] that is spawn by the Apache HC HttpAsyncClient callback and the second time from the requesting thread at the interceptor chain [4]; Thus the camel-cxf client callback is also invoked twice!
[3] https://github.com/apache/cxf/blob/cxf-3.1.8/rt/transports/http/src/main/java/org/apache/cxf/transport/http/HTTPConduit.java#L1177
[4] https://github.com/apache/cxf/blob/cxf-3.1.8/core/src/main/java/org/apache/cxf/phase/PhaseInterceptorChain.java#L366
And if Camel's CxfClientCallback is invoked more than once, the superfluous and erroneous exchange penetrates the last processor iteration of the Try/Catch DSL and hijacks the subsequent route steps, which then terminates the route as it contains an exception.

I think this second issue has to be fixed. It's a CXF issue and CXF should really enforce that every client callback be invoked once and only once in general.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
I have attached a test route reproducer-context.xml to reproduce the issue. The route reads from an activemq queue and uses cxf to send it to an http endpoint.
The destination http endpoint does not exist and this is the expected configuration for reproducing the issue,

Note: make sure fuse is configured with async http client so that cxf can use it. install cxf-http-async feature.

Once test route is deployed, post the test-input.xml to the queue through hawtio. You will see the exception in the log.

Running same test on RHEL7.2 cannot get the exception.
